plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub known for its glossy leaves and large, rose-like flowers that bloom in winter, providing vibrant color in colder months.
plants.location: East Asia (Japan, China, Korea); also widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellias were named after the Jesuit botanist Georg Kamel, and their blooms are often used in traditional Japanese tea ceremonies.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A hardy perennial that produces white to pinkish flowers often blooming around Christmas in Europe, thriving in shady garden areas and woodland edges.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose but belongs to the buttercup family and can bloom through snow.

plants.name: Leptospermum scoparium
plants.description: A small tree or shrub native to New Zealand and southeastern Australia, known for its delicate white or pink flowers and its honey, which is prized for medicinal properties.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring to late summer in Southern Hemisphere (November to February)
plants.funFact: Manuka honey, derived from the nectar of Manuka flowers, is renowned worldwide for its antibacterial qualities.

plants.name: Acacia dealbata
plants.description: A fast-growing tree that produces bright yellow, fluffy flowers in late winter to early spring, commonly used in floristry and as an ornamental plant.
plants.bloomingSeason: January to March in Southern Hemisphere
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia; cultivated in Mediterranean climates
plants.funFact: The Silver Wattle was traditionally used by Indigenous Australians for wood and dyes and is also associated with International Women's Day in some countries due to its vivid yellow flowers.
